statements.text: Six-year-old Falcon Heene from Fort Collins, Colorado, was reported to have floated away in a homemade experimental balloon but was later found safe hiding in his family’s attic.
The Larimer County sheriff announced Falcon’s discovery at 6:11 p.m. after a large search operation involving local police and residents.
Authorities initially believed Falcon was inside a box attached to the balloon, though reports about the box’s existence were conflicting.
Sheriff spokeswoman Kathy Messick said the box was found damaged, while The New York Times identified it as part of the balloon’s compartment.
Fort Collins police clarified that the balloon was never designed to carry people and was part of a family science project.
The balloon landed south of Prospect Springs after reaching around 7,000 feet, and witnesses reported seeing something fall from it.
Police searched based on statements from Falcon’s brothers, who claimed he climbed inside the balloon before it detached and drifted away.
Authorities later concluded that Falcon had been hiding to avoid punishment rather than being inside the balloon.
Falcon’s father, Richard Heene, a storm chaser and scientist, said the family built the experimental balloon to explore transportation ideas for commuters.
Richard and his wife Naomi previously appeared on the U.S. TV show 'Wife Swap,' and Richard was featured on an ABC News segment about storm chasing.
